metadata.titleEn: High temporal and spatial resolution precipitation data of Upper Brahmaputra River Basin (1981-2019)
metadata.description:
This data set is the version 2 of "High temporal and spatial resolution precipitation data of Upper Brahmaputra River Basin (1981-2016) ", with additional data from 2017 to 2019.
This data set describes the temporal and spatial distribution of precipitation in the Upper Brahmaputra River Basin. We integrate (CMA, GLDAS, ITP-Forcing, MERRA2, TRMM) five sets of reanalysis precipitation products and satellite precipitation products, and combine the observation precipitation of 9 national meteorological stations from China Meteorological Administration (CMA) and 166 rain gauges of the Ministry of Water Resources (MWR) in the basin. The time range is 1981-2019, the time resolution is 3 hours, the spatial resolution is 5 km, and the unit is mm/h. The data will provide better data support for the study of Upper Brahmaputra River Basin, and can be used to study the response of hydrological process to climate change. Please refer to the instruction document uploaded with the data for specific usage information.
metadata.instructions:
For the convenience of users, the data is stored in the format of TXT, one file per month. The name is "prec_integrated_yyyymm.txt", where yyyy represents the year and mm represents the month. Each file is internally stored with 248 (January, March, May, July, August, October, December), 240 (April, June, September, November), 224 or 232 (February) precipitation spatial distribution. The number of rows and columns of each distribution is 292 * 79, arranged in time sequence (0, 3, 6, 9...o'clock). Add the header file information to each image to open it with ArcGIS. The header file information is as follows:
ncols 292
nrows 79
xllcorner 20968.258085928
yllcorner 3078203.0630637
cellsize 5000
NODATA_value -9999

background: Precipitation in the basin is mainly controlled by the Indian summer monsoon and westerly and is the key to understanding the water resources available in the basin; however, due to sparse observational data constrained by a harsh environment and complex topography, there remains a lack of reliable information on basin-wide precipitation (there are only nine national meteorological stations with continuous observations). The Tibetan Plateau (TP), known as the highest plateau in the world, is covered by massive glaciers, snow, and permafrost, which significantly affect the hydrological processes of all the large rivers that are fed by it: the Brahmaputra, the Salween, and the Mekong, among others. However, due to the irregular and sparse distribution of national meteorological stations, particularly in the upper Brahmaputra (precipitation data from only nine stations are available and are sparsely distributed), there are large data constraints on research on these hydrological processes and their responses to climate change. Although there are many more rain gauges managed by the Ministry of Water Resources (MWR), most of them are located in middle-stream regions, and rainfall datasets are only recorded over short time periods. Accurate spatial distributions of precipitation are unavailable. Most studies have focused on evapotranspiration, soil moisture, and groundwater products derived from GLDAS or MERRA2; meanwhile, to the best of our knowledge, there has been less focus on the evaluation of methods of precipitation estimation and little work on the corresponding river discharge simulations within the upper Brahmaputra River basin. These precipitation products generally have the advantage of wide and consistent coverage and have shown great potential in many applications but also suffer from large uncertainties over the upper Brahmaputra River basin due to indirect observations, insufficient gauge calibration, and complex topography.
research objective: In this study, we focus on integrating gauge, satellite, and reanalysis precipitation datasets to generate a new dataset over the upper Brahmaputra, suitable for use in hydrological simulations and other scientific research related to climate change.
challenges: Furthermore, no products used in this study accurately represent extreme precipitation events; thus, it is necessary to improve the ability of all of these products to capture extreme events.
methods: To improve the accuracy of basin-wide precipitation data, we integrate various gauge, satellite, and reanalysis precipitation datasets, including GLDAS, ITP-Forcing, MERRA2, TRMM, and CMA datasets, to develop a new precipitation product for the 1981–2016 period over the upper Brahmaputra River basin, at 3 h and 5 km resolution. The new product has been rigorously validated at different temporal scales (e.g., extreme events, daily to monthly variability, and long-term trends) and spatial scales (point and basin scale) with gauge precipitation observations.
dataset: The new precipitation product has been rigorously validated at different temporal scales (e.g., extreme events, daily to monthly variability, and long-term trends) and spatial scales (point and basin scale) with gauge precipitation observations, showing much improved accuracies compared to previous products.
findings: An improved hydrological simulation has been achieved (low relative bias: −5.94 %; highest Nash–Sutcliffe coefficient of efficiency (NSE): 0.643) with the new precipitation inputs, showing reliability and potential for multidisciplinary studies.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how a combination of gauge, satellite, and reanalysis datasets can improve the accuracy of precipitation data collection in regions with sparse observational coverage?
Example.Answer: An example of this approach is the integration of various datasets like GLDAS, ITP-Forcing, MERRA2, TRMM, and CMA to develop a new precipitation product for the upper Brahmaputra River basin. This method improved the spatial and temporal resolution of precipitation data by combining different sources, leading to more accurate hydrological simulations.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge encountered when estimating precipitation in regions with complex topography, and how can it be addressed?
Example.Answer: A significant challenge is the large uncertainties in precipitation estimates due to indirect observations and insufficient gauge calibration, particularly in regions like the upper Brahmaputra River basin. This can be addressed by integrating multiple datasets and rigorously validating the new precipitation product at different temporal and spatial scales with gauge observations.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of how improved precipitation datasets can enhance hydrological simulations and research related to climate change?
Example.Answer: With the new precipitation inputs developed by integrating multiple datasets, improved hydrological simulations were achieved, showing a low relative bias of −5.94% and the highest Nash–Sutcliffe coefficient of efficiency (NSE) of 0.643. This demonstrates the potential for these datasets to enhance research on hydrological processes and their responses to climate change.

Feature Specification.Answer: 3-hour temporal resolution, 5 km spatial resolution, integrates data from CMA, GLDAS, ITP-Forcing, MERRA2, TRMM, includes observations from national meteorological stations, includes observations from Ministry of Water Resources rain gauges

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'validation at different temporal scales' in the context of developing new precipitation products?
Definition.Answer: Validation at different temporal scales involves assessing the accuracy of a precipitation dataset by comparing it with observed data over various time intervals, such as extreme events, daily, monthly, and long-term trends, to ensure its reliability for modeling and research purposes.

Comparison.Question: How do the integrated gauge, satellite, and reanalysis precipitation datasets compare to traditional gauge-only datasets in terms of capturing extreme precipitation events in the Brahmaputra River basin?
Comparison.Answer: The integrated datasets improve the accuracy of capturing basin-wide precipitation, but none accurately represent extreme precipitation events. The integration of various datasets aims to improve these representations, unlike gauge-only datasets which suffer from sparse distribution and short recording periods.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data accuracy between the new precipitation product and previous precipitation products in the context of hydrological simulation for the Brahmaputra River basin?
Comparison.Answer: The new precipitation product demonstrates much improved accuracies compared to previous products. It shows low relative bias and a higher Nash–Sutcliffe coefficient of efficiency (NSE), indicating improved reliability in hydrological simulations.

Interpretation.Question: What can the integration of gauge, satellite, and reanalysis precipitation datasets reveal about the spatial and temporal distribution of precipitation in complex topographical areas?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of these datasets can reveal more accurate spatial and temporal distributions of precipitation, overcoming data constraints caused by sparse observational data and complex topography. This integration helps in generating a new dataset suitable for hydrological simulations and climate change research.

Interpretation.Question: How might the challenges in accurately representing extreme precipitation events affect the interpretation of hydrological simulations in the upper Brahmaputra River basin?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges in representing extreme precipitation events may lead to uncertainties in hydrological simulations, affecting the reliability of conclusions drawn about water resource availability and hydrological responses to climate change in the basin. Improving the capture of extreme events is necessary for more reliable simulations.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do the improved accuracies of precipitation products have for future research on climate change impacts in the Brahmaputra River basin?
Interpretation.Answer: The improved accuracies of precipitation products imply that future research can achieve more reliable hydrological simulations and analyses of climate change impacts. This enhanced data accuracy supports multidisciplinary studies, providing a stronger foundation for understanding climate-related changes in the region.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately representing extreme precipitation events in datasets related to the upper Brahmaputra River basin?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Extreme precipitation events are not accurately represented due to indirect observations, insufficient gauge calibration, and complex topography, which contribute to large uncertainties in the datasets.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a lack of reliable information on basin-wide precipitation in the upper Brahmaputra River basin?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The lack of reliable information is caused by sparse observational data constrained by a harsh environment and complex topography, and the irregular and sparse distribution of national meteorological stations, particularly in the upper Brahmaputra.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the outcomes of integrating multiple sources such as gauge, satellite, and reanalysis precipitation datasets for data collection in the upper Brahmaputra River basin?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiple sources results in a new dataset suitable for hydrological simulations and scientific research related to climate change, with improved spatial and temporal accuracy, especially in extreme events and long-term trends.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of sparse observational data and complex topography on precipitation data accuracy in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Sparse observational data and complex topography lead to large uncertainties in precipitation data due to indirect observations and insufficient gauge calibration, affecting the reliability of hydrological process research and climate change response studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of integrating multiple gauge, satellite, and reanalysis precipitation datasets for data collection in the Brahmaputra River basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to generate a new dataset over the upper Brahmaputra that is suitable for use in hydrological simulations and other scientific research related to climate change, by improving the accuracy of basin-wide precipitation data.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to address the challenges of capturing extreme precipitation events in the creation of a dataset?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important because no current products accurately represent extreme precipitation events, which is necessary to improve the ability of all products to capture these events for better hydrological simulations and climate research.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can different precipitation datasets be integrated to improve the accuracy of hydrological simulations in regions with sparse observational data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To improve the accuracy of basin-wide precipitation data, various gauge, satellite, and reanalysis precipitation datasets, including GLDAS, ITP-Forcing, MERRA2, TRMM, and CMA datasets, can be integrated. This approach has been validated at different temporal and spatial scales with gauge precipitation observations to ensure improved accuracy over previous products.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps required to validate a new precipitation dataset over a complex topographic region?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The validation of a new precipitation dataset involves rigorous assessment at different temporal scales, such as extreme events, daily to monthly variability, and long-term trends, as well as at different spatial scales, including point and basin scale validations with gauge precipitation observations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approaches can be employed to address the challenge of accurately capturing extreme precipitation events in a complex topographic basin?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address the challenge of accurately capturing extreme precipitation events, it is necessary to enhance the capability of integrated precipitation products by improving the calibration and validation processes, using a combination of gauge, satellite, and reanalysis datasets to better represent these events.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the integration of various gauge, satellite, and reanalysis datasets to improve the accuracy of precipitation data in complex topographies?
Enablement.Answer: The integration involves using GLDAS, ITP-Forcing, MERRA2, TRMM, and CMA datasets to develop a new precipitation product, validated against gauge observations at different temporal and spatial scales.

Enablement.Question: What are the necessary conditions for improving precipitation datasets to accurately represent extreme precipitation events in hydrological research?
Enablement.Answer: Improving the ability of products to capture extreme events is necessary, as current datasets do not accurately represent them, indicating a need for enhanced methods and validation processes.

Expectation.Question: Why might existing datasets struggle to accurately represent precipitation distribution across the upper Brahmaputra River basin?
Expectation.Answer: Existing datasets may struggle due to the sparse distribution of national meteorological stations, particularly in the upper Brahmaputra, and the limitations of rain gauges which are often located in middle-stream regions. Additionally, indirect observations, insufficient gauge calibration, and complex topography contribute to large uncertainties in these datasets.

Expectation.Question: What expectations should researchers have when integrating multiple precipitation datasets to improve hydrological simulations?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers should expect that integrating various gauge, satellite, and reanalysis precipitation datasets can significantly improve the accuracy of precipitation data. This integration could result in better hydrological simulations, as demonstrated by low relative bias and improved Nash–Sutcliffe coefficient of efficiency, indicating reliability and potential for multidisciplinary studies.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to capture extreme precipitation events accurately in existing precipitation products?
Expectation.Answer: Capturing extreme precipitation events accurately is challenging due to the limitations of current products that do not accurately represent these events. This suggests a need for further improvement in the ability of these products to capture extreme events, likely due to indirect observations and insufficient calibration of available datasets.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of integrating various precipitation datasets in overcoming the challenges of sparse observational data in complex topographies?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of various precipitation datasets, such as gauge, satellite, and reanalysis datasets, effectively addresses the challenges posed by sparse observational data and complex topography. It improves the accuracy of basin-wide precipitation data, which is crucial for reliable hydrological simulations and research on climate change impacts.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the primary limitations of current precipitation datasets for capturing extreme weather events in the Brahmaputra River basin?
Judgmental.Answer: Current precipitation datasets have limitations in accurately representing extreme precipitation events due to indirect observations, insufficient gauge calibration, and the complex topography of the Brahmaputra River basin. Improving the ability of these products to capture extreme events is necessary for more accurate hydrological simulations.

Judgmental.Question: Can the integration of multiple datasets be considered a reliable method for improving hydrological simulations and how does it compare to previous methods?
Judgmental.Answer: Yes, the integration of multiple datasets is a reliable method for improving hydrological simulations, as it shows much improved accuracies compared to previous products. This method has been validated at different temporal and spatial scales, leading to better simulation results with lower relative bias and higher efficiency coefficients.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how the accuracy of a new precipitation dataset is rigorously validated at different temporal and spatial scales.
Assertion.Answer: The accuracy is validated by comparing the new dataset's precipitation observations with gauge observations across different temporal scales, such as extreme events and long-term trends, and spatial scales, including point and basin scales, to ensure improved accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand why extreme precipitation events are difficult to represent accurately in precipitation datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Extreme precipitation events are challenging to represent accurately because the existing datasets often lack the resolution or calibration necessary to capture these events precisely, which is compounded by the complex topography and sparse data distribution in the region.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and evaluate the challenges faced in the data collection process for hydrological simulations and climate change studies in the upper Brahmaputra River basin.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include sparse observational data due to harsh environments and complex topography, limited gauge calibration, and irregular distribution of meteorological stations. There are large data constraints due to insufficient observations and indirect data sources. Furthermore, existing products do not accurately represent extreme precipitation events, necessitating improvements in capturing these events.

Request/Directive.Question: Please suggest methodologies for improving the accuracy of precipitation datasets used in hydrological and climate change studies in complex topographical regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Methodologies include integrating multiple datasets (gauge, satellite, reanalysis) and performing rigorous validation at various scales. This approach helps in capturing extreme events and improving the accuracy of basin-wide precipitation data. It is vital to address indirect observations and sparse gauge calibration to overcome uncertainties in complex topographical regions.
